question: If you are a dog owner, which two things should your dog's collar have when you go out for a walk?
Which TWO of these were introduced before the First World War in 1914?
tip: Financial help for the unemployed, old-age pensions and free school meals were just a few of the important measures introduced.

Who used a system of land ownership known as feudalism?
What are traditional pub games? (Select TWO)
tip: Most communities will have a ‘local’ pub that is a natural focal point for social activities. Pub quizzes are popular. Pool and darts are traditional pub games.

question: What is the geographic position of the UK in Europe?
tip: The UK is located in the North West of Europe.

question: Any man who forces a woman to have sex, including a woman's husband, can be charged with rape
options: No, if he is married he has the right to do it

question: When did the 'Battle of the Boyne' happen?
tip: James II wanted to regain the throne and invaded Ireland with the help of a French army. William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690, an event which is still celebrated by some in Northern Ireland today. William re-conquered Ireland and James fled back to France.

question: Which of these drugs can you buy or sell legally in UK?
tip: Selling or buying drugs such as heroin, cocaine, ecstasy and cannabis is illegal in the UK.

question: MPs can only be contacted by post.
Drivers can use their driving licence until they are 70 years old.
tip: Drivers can use their driving licence until they are 70 years old.

question: What do children do on Father's Day for their fathers?
Which general remains a controversial figure in Ireland?
tip: Cromwell was successful in establishing the authority of the English Parliament in Ireland but did this with such violence that even today Cromwell remains a controversial figure.

question: What countries does 'Great Britain' refer to?
tip: 'Great Britain' refers only to England, Scotland and Wales, not to Northern Ireland. The official name of the country is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

question: Two British film actors who have recently won Oscars are
It is a legal requirement that men and women should not be discriminated against due to their gender or marital status
tip: UK laws ensure that people are not treated unfairly in any area of life or work because of their age, disability, sex, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion or belief, sexuality or marital status.

question: The United Kingdom is made up of
In Scotland, the national Church is the Church of Scotland, which is a ______
What kind of event is The Wimbledon Championship?
tip: Tennis evolved in England in the late 19th century. The first tennis club was founded in Leamington Spa in 1872. The most famous tournament hosted in Britain is The Wimbledon Championships, which takes place each year at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club. It is the oldest tennis tournament in the world and the only ‘Grand Slam’ event played on grass.

question: Which British TV shows are popular in the UK now?
tip: Popular programmes include regular soap operas such as Coronation Street and EastEnders.

question: The Welsh language, spoken in Wales and is taught in schools and universities, is a completely different language from English
tip: The English language has many accents and dialects. In Wales, many people speak Welsh – a completely different language from English – and it is taught in schools and universities. In Scotland, Gaelic (again, a different language) is spoken in some parts of the Highlands and Islands, and in Northern Ireland some people speak Irish Gaelic.

question: Women over 21 were allowed to vote for the first time in 1969
tip: The voting franchise was also extended to women over 30, and then in 1928 to men and women over 21. In 1969, the voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.

question: When do pubs usually open?
tip: Public Houses, also known as Pubs, usually open at 11:00 AM, 12:00 PM on Sundays.

question: How can you help looking after the environment?
tip: It is important to recycle as much of your waste as you can. Using recycled materials to make new products uses less energy and means that we do not need to extract more raw materials from the earth. It also means that less rubbish is created, so the amount being put into landfill is reduced.

question: When a member of Parliament (MP) resigns or dies, what is the election called that is held to replace them?
St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the
Why is 1969 a very important year in British history?
options: Women were given the right to vote
Women were given the right to vote at the age of 30
Women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, same as men
Women were given the right to vote at the age of 18
tip: The voting franchise was also extended to women over 30, and then in 1928 to men and women over 21. In 1969, the voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.

question: Which two issues can the devolved administrations pass laws on?
As a resident of the UK your responsibilities should be
options: Vote for the government in power
Take in and look after stray animals

question: The jury decides on the penalty if the defendant is found guilty
tip: The jury has to listen to the evidence presented at the trial and then decide a verdict of ‘guilty’ or ‘not guilty’ based on what they have heard. In Scotland, a third verdict of ‘not proven’ is also possible. If the jury finds a defendant guilty, the judge decides on the penalty.

question: What building was constructed in Hyde Park to hold the Great Exhibition of 1851?
The Proms
options: are a series of tennis matches held every July in London
is an eight week summer season of orchestral music

question: The Northern Ireland Assembly was established soon after the Belfast Agreement in ______
Which country became formally united with England during the reign of Henry VIII?
tip: During the reign of Henry VIII, Wales became formally united with England by the Act for the Government of Wales. The Welsh sent representatives to the House of Commons and the Welsh legal system was reformed.

question: Examples of civil law are:
Who is the author of 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'?
tip: Roald Dahl was born in Wales to Norwegian parents. He served in the Royal Air Force during the Second World War. His best-known works include Charlie and the Chocolate Factory and George's Marvellous Medicine.

question: The Speaker of the House of Commons is
In the years leading up to ______, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage
In Scotland, 31 December is called ______
For which types of literature is William Shakespeare famous?
Who was the monarch when the Book of Common Prayer was written to be used in the Church of England?
tip: Henry VIII was succeeded by his son Edward VI, who was strongly Protestant. During his reign, the Book of Common Prayer was written to be used in the Church of England. A version of this book is still used in some churches today.

question: The UK is a parliamentary democracy with ______ as head of state
Oliver Cromwell took the title 'King of Ireland'
tip: Cromwell was given the title of Lord Protector and ruled until his death in 1658. Henry VIII took the title 'King of Ireland'

question: There are a few MPs (Members of Parliament) who do not represent any of the main political parties
options: Yes, this is correct They are called 'independents'
No, All MPs have to belong to a political party

question: 20th century British inventions or discoveries are:
Giving blood only takes about ______ to do
Which of the devolved administrations has been suspended a few times?
tip: There has been a Welsh Assembly and a Scottish Parliament since 1999. There is a Northern Ireland Assembly, although this has been suspended on a few occasions.

question: Other than London universities, which university was credited with the discovery of the DNA molecule in 1953?
tip: The structure of the DNA molecule was discovered in 1953 through work at British universities in London and Cambridge. This discovery contributed to many scientific advances, particularly in medicine and fighting crime. Francis Crick (1916–2004), one of those awarded the Nobel Prize for this discovery, was British.

question: A husband who forces his wife to have sex can be charged with rape.
tip: Any man who forces a woman to have sex, including a woman's husband, can be charged with rape.

question: Henry VIII’s fourth wife, Anne of Cleves was a Spanish princess
tip: Anne of Cleves was a German princess. Henry married her for political reasons but divorced her soon after.
